ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great introduction to business ethics. Really great discussions.
Learned to critically evaluate different branches of capitalism

Foundations of business ethics, classical to modern. Thought a lot about the ethical foundations of capitalism and the profit motive. Debate skills improved. As a capitalist I became more skeptical of capitalism in this course, and my hardline socialist classmates became more receptive of it, so it's a win-win for everyone. First time I've ever read Rawls or Keynes.
I learned a lot about classic economic thinkers and the debates that happened around all the principles that econ classes simply state as fact.
I learned a great deal about important philosophers and capitalism.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
- Good coverage of a lot of material
- Well-selected readings

Weaknesses:
- I felt like the emphasis on more modern thinkers wasn't very thorough.

Strengths: we got introduced to a wide range of capitalist thought 

Weakness: we didnt read any anti-capitalists apart from Marx, neither did we discuss the real-world ramifications of different thinkers thoughts

I really liked the readings and the way that Professor Collins would put key words/concepts on the board at the beginning of class. I didnt like the midterm. Quote memorization felt like a waste of time to me and I didnt feel like I learnt from it

Strengths: Clear and organized syllabus that moved in conversation with previous authors in chronological order, midterm and papers facilitated understanding and deeper examination of topics. Readings were interesting every time. Secondary literature provided good modern interpretations and applications of primary authors. Class dynamic was fun and thoughtful. 
Weaknesses: Lots of time to summarize what the authors wrote, not enough time to think about our own opinions. Final paper was rather unstructuredit would have been nice if we had a list of topics instead of needing to come up with our own. Class was focused on answering one question: is capitalism a force for moral good? If you're not interested in that question, you're out of luck.

Strengths: Professor Collins is great! He explained concepts very well and made them fun and engaging with little games and examples.
Weaknesses: often we wouldn't finish talking about a thinker one week and have to finish the next week, which I found challenging because I would forget a lot of the reading and feel a little lost in class. No significant weaknesses though.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would if you are interested in exploring different branches of capitalism. I would not recommend if you are looking for an anti-capitalist class

This is an excellent introduction to the foundational thinkers of business ethicsspoilers, here's the full lineup of thinkers: Aristotle, Aquinas, Locke, Smith, Hume, Montesquieu, Mill, Weber, Marx, Keynes, Hayek, Friedman, Rawlsand contemporaries McCloskey, Cowen, Robert Reich and Stiglitz. And random academic commentators and articles. If you're interested in any of these people's ideas and how they interact with each other, take this class! You won't regret this opportunity to think about the foundations of our modern capitalist system and how we can be more self-aware of the implications behind it, and how to respond appropriately as participants. A lot of the class is focused on the opinions of the thinkers in the syllabus and not too much on developing our own opinions, but that is just fine because students come in with their own implicit biases on this sort of contentious questionis capitalism a force for moral good? Class revolves mostly around this question.

Yes! Professor Collins is great, and you will come away with a really good understanding of the theory behind things you learn in econ classes. I think every econ/EPE major should have to take a class like this.

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. Professor Collins is an incredibly thoughtful, thorough professor, who ensures that all of his students not only understand but actively participate in the discussions regarding capitalism and various thinkers. This course is also incredibly valuable in that it allows students to develop their own perspectives on capitalism, without the course being biased from the start.
